_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Rohm and Haas Chemicals, LLC - Louisville Plant
Risk Management Plan Resubmittal June A`09
Executive Summary

1.0    Introduction

The Rohm and Haas Chemicals, LLC Louisville Plant (Rohm and Haas Louisville) is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes safely and responsibly.  Our continuing work to prevent accidents and releases from occurring, as well as our preparations to respond to accidents if they should occur, help to ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This summary provides an overview of the many risk management activities at the site, and a discussion of our response to the EPAA?s Risk Management Program.  This summary includes:

2.0    General Facility Information
3.0    The EPAA?s Risk Management Program
4.0    Regulated Substances
5.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
6.0    The Rohm and Haas Louisville Accident Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
7.0    Five Year Accident History
8.0    Emergency Response Program 
9.0    Worst Case and Alternative Case Release Scenarios
10.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

2.0    General Facility Information

Rohm and Haas Louisville is a specialty chemical manufacturing facility located in the Rubbertown Area.  The plant started during World War II, as part of several facilities the government sponsored to produce synthetic rubber for the war effort.  After the war, the government-owned plant was inactive except for a brief time during the Korean War.  Rohm and Haas Company, a major U.S. chemical producer, bought the Louisville site in 1960.

Today, Rohm and Haas Louisville produces over 200 different products.  They are sold to other manufacturers who use them as key components in a wide variety of consumer products.  The three main product families are:  
A?    Plastic additives make plastic tough and moldable.  Plastic additives are used in many products, including bottles, containers, medical supplies, piping, house s

iding, window frames, and car bumpers.
A?    Emulsion products are used primarily as coatings and binders.  Emulsion products are used in latex paint, floor polishes, adhesives, inks, coatings and binders for paper products, as well as caulking, cement and concrete.
A?    Acrylic coatings are noted for their toughness and shine.  Acrylic coatings provide the finish for boats and the touch-up paint for cars.  The coatings also beautify and protect signs and steel.  They are used on metal furniture, the painted part of pencils, and the lining of soft drink cans.

Rohm and Haas Louisville produces approximately one billion pounds of product annually, has 257 employees with annual payroll and benefits of $38 million, and pays approximately $0.9 million annually in taxes (not including income tax).  Rohm and Haas contributes to many charitable organizations in the community. 

3.0    The EPAA?s Risk Management Program

In a series of rules promulgated between 1994 and 1998, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency established the Risk Management Program (RMP) under Clean Air Act  112(r).  The RMP contains a list of toxic and flammable chemicals.  Facilities that manage more than a threshold amount of a listed chemical may be subject to the RMP.  Covered facilities must assess the risks associated with their management of the listed chemicals and produce a plan to prevent releases and accidents.  In order to assist in emergency planning, covered facilities must evaluate A?worst caseA? and A?alternate caseA? scenarios that would result from the release of a listed chemical.  Finally, the covered facility must make their risk management program available to the public.  This document is part of Rohm and Haas LouisvilleA?s RMP communication effort.  

4.0    Regulated Substances

Our plant uses three chemicals which are regulated by the RMP: 
A?    1,3-butadiene monomer, an RMP flammable used in the production of plastic modifiers, 

A?    Acrylonitrile monomer,  an RMP toxic that is

a basis for some emulsion polymers, and 

A?    Aqueous ammonia, an RMP toxic consisting of 30% ammonia in water, which is used in the production of acrylic emulsions. 

5.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy       

Rohm and Haas Louisville has a long standing commitment to provide a safe workplace and to prevent accidental releases.  This commitment is set forth in Rohm and Haas Company environmental, health and safety policies:
    
    We will ensure our worldwide operations and products are free from significant risks to the health and safety of our employees, customers, carriers, distributors, the general public, and to the environment.
    
    We will meet or exceed all applicable laws and regulations, participate in voluntary initiatives such as Responsible CareA? and strive for continual improvement in our Environmental, Health, and Safety performance.
    
    We will provide our employees with a safe workplace and support their efforts to work safely.
    
    We will strive to eliminate or reduce emissions, discharges, and wastes from every stage of our operations.
    
    We will communicate, listen and be responsive to our employees, customers, neighbors, and governments, and we will share information concerning potential hazards resulting from our operations or our products.

The types of risk management programs required by the RMP have long been in place at Rohm and Haas Louisville.  Safe operation is a plant and company priority, and is reflected in policies as well as everyday activities. We welcome the EPAA?s RMP initiative and see it as an opportunity to expand dialog with our community and to help us improve our safety performance. 

6.0    The Rohm and Haas Louisville Accident Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps  

Rohm and Haas Louisville maintains a number of accident prevention programs in order to ensure safe operation of all processes.  For example, the plant complies with OSHAA?s Proce

ss Safety Management (PSM) rule, which are nearly identical to EPAA?s Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. Additionally, the Plant follows corporate and plant-specific safety standards, which in some cases are more stringent than the OSHA general safety standards.  The following items are part of our ongoing program to prevent releases and incidents:  .

1)     Employee Participation A? Employees are involved in many activities to continuously improve plant safety.  Employees participate in safety committees, job safety analysis, audits, inspections, design and pre-startup EHS reviews, process hazard analysis, training, procedure development and monthly safety meetings.

2)    Process Hazard Analysis - Various process hazard analysis techniques are used to identify and analyze the potential hazards associated with the chemicals and processes we use. Corrective action plans are developed and implemented as part of the analyses and updated a minimum of every five years. Safety systems are designed into the processes.  These are designed to create several layers of protection, so that if one system fails other systems will maintain the process in a safe state.  Examples include:
 
    Redundant safety systems and instrumentation, particularly for tank level systems
    Automatic shutdown devices that are triggered if critical safety equipment malfunctions
    Secondary containment for storage tanks
    Alarm systems and automatic shutdown devices for critical control parameters
    Pressure relief devices to prevent overpressurization
    Fire protection systems
    Operator surveillance of unloading operations
    Permit system to control work in hazardous areas
    Work preplanning and safety reviews

3)    Operating Procedures A? Operating procedures have been developed for all processes to insure safe operation.  Employees that operate the manufacturing process are included in the development, training and periodic review of these

procedures.  Our processes are ISO A? 9002 certified. 

4)    Employee Training A? Training programs have been developed and implemented  to ensure that all affected employees understand the hazards of the chemicals and the required safe handling procedures.  Employees involved in operating the manufacturing processes are trained, tested, and qualified.
  
5)    Mechanical Integrity A? This program was established to ensure the integrity of process equipment.  Elements of this program include:

A?    Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation
A?    Inspections and tests
A?    Establishment of inspection frequencies
A?    Development and application of maintenance procedures
A?    Training of maintenance personnel
A?    Documentation of tests and inspection results

6)    Pre-Startup Safety (EHS) Reviews A? Safety reviews of new processes, major projects, and new chemicals are conducted to ensure safe transition into the manufacturing process.  

7)    Hot Work Permit A? This system manages welding, cutting, brazing and other ignition sources throughout the plant to prevent fires and explosions.

8)    Management of Change A? This procedure is in place to properly manage the changes involving processes, chemicals, technology, equipment or facilities. 

9)    Contractor Training and Safety Reviews A? Contractors are evaluated to ensure they have the appropriate job skills, knowledge, training and certification to perform their assigned work safely.  The primary plant contractor has an on-site safety supervisor.  The safety performance of contractors is periodically reviewed.

10)    Incident Investigation A? Any incidents or near misses involving the release of hazardous material are investigated by a team of skilled and knowledgeable plant personnel.  These investigations identify corrective actions, evaluate our management systems and are documented and communicated throughout the company in a narrative report.  Any required corrective actions are tracked for timely completion.

11)    Compliance Audits A? Audits of our Process Safety Management System are conducted  every three years.  These audits review accident prevention activities to ensure the requirements of the programs are being met. 

7.0    Five Year Accident History

The RMP rule requires each company to include a description of all accidental releases from covered processes that result in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  The Rohm and Haas Louisville plant had no events meeting this criteria during the last five years.

8.0    Emergency Response Program 

The Rohm and Haas Louisville plant has an emergency response plan that is coordinated with the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), Lake Dreamland Fire Department, Rubbertown Mutual Aid Association, and other local response agencies. New employees are trained prior to working in a process area and plant personnel review the plan during annual safety meetings.  The plant has an extensive alarm system, which includes key alarms also sounding in the plant gate house. Most processes have remote shutdown capability, including those covered by RMP.  The plant has an on-site state-recognized fire department, with mobile fire protection vehicles as well as state-licensed ambulance service.  The siteA?s 24-hour emergency response team can respond to both on-site and transportation off-site hazardous materials releases. The site has direct radio contact with off-site responders and the ability to activate the community siren system.  Plant drills to practice proper response are held at least annually.

 9.0    Worst Case and Alternative Case Release Scenarios

The RMP rule provides detailed requirements that define a worst case scenario (WCS), namely a release of the entire contents of the largest storage vessel  occurring  under very stable weather conditions and at a low wind speed. EPA note

s that the worse-case scenario is designed principally to support a dialogue between the source and the community on release prevention, and not to serve as the sole or primary basis for emergency planning. Based on previous history, in addition to the several layers of protection in place, these worse-case scenarios are highly unlikely to actually occur.

The RMP rule also defines the alternate release scenario (ARS). Unlike worse-case scenarios, the ARS can be limited by active mitigation safeguards, such as alarms, automatic shutdowns, and operator interventions.   According to EPA, an ARS is a more useful communication tool for the public and first responders and for emergency response preparedness and planning. 

Worst Case Scenarios:  
Rohm and Haas Louisville has identified two WCS based on the RMP definition: one for a toxic material and one for a flammable material.  The following is a description of our scenarios:

Worst Case Toxic
This scenario involves acrylonitrile, which is considered a toxic material under the RMP rule.   It assumes the loss of the entire inventory of 275,000 pound from a catastrophic failure of the storage tank into the containment dike, releasing vapors over a 60 minute period.  The EPAA?s tabulated dispersion predictions were used to determine the toxic endpoint of this release and such a release could have a significant off-site impact.  Because of the plant controls, procedures and training, the worse case event is extremely unlikely. 

Worst Case Flammable  
This scenario involves releasing the maximum inventory of 1,3-butadiene from the storage tank.  Administrative procedures, controls and alarms limit the maximum inventory to 600,000 pounds.  1,3-butadiene is a flammable substance under the RMP rule.  The RMP rule assumes the entire vessel contents would be released, ignited, and results in a vapor cloud explosion.  We have applied EPAA?s guidance and predicted endpoint distances to a one psi overpressure.  A vapor cloud expl

osion of the maximum inventory would have an effect on the Rohm and Haas site as well as on our near industrial and residential neighbors.  There are prevention and mitigation equipment and systems in place to minimize this possibility. Trained operators are assigned to the storage area.  The 1,3 butadiene tanks are covered by the process safety management program and undergo integrity testing and inspections on a routine basis.  The area is constantly monitored with gas detectors.  Temperature detectors are tied into a water deluge system surrounding the storage tank. Because of the plant controls, procedures and training, the worse case event is extremely unlikely.

Alternate Release Scenario

Rohm and Haas Louisville has identified three ARS: one for each toxic material (2) and one for butadiene, the flammable material.  These scenarios were chosen after reviewing process hazard analysis, the plant spill history, and discussing alternatives with knowledgeable and experienced unit personnel.  The scenarios we have identified are more credible than those described in the worst case, but are still very unlikely given of the multiple levels of protection and extensive employee training.

Alternate Release Scenario - Acrylonitrile (Toxic Liquid)
The RMP rule requires an alternate release scenario be picked for each covered toxic material. The following is the alternate scenario description for acrylonitrile:
Beyond the storage tank containment area, the transfer line to the production unit is welded without gasketed flanges or drains.  However if a A? inch drain valve on the transfer line within the containment dike were left open, the entire contents of the transfer line would be drained and 1,000 pounds of acrylonitrile would be released into the containment dike.  Gas detectors would sound an alarm in the control room and automatically close the tank bottom valve. The EPAA?s tabulated dispersion predictions for alternate release scenarios was used to determine the

toxic endpoint.  This release could effect plant employees, and the employees of the plant to the north or to the south, depending on the weather conditions and the wind direction.  There are no residences or environmental receptors within the alternate release toxic endpoint circle.  

 Alternate Release Scenario A? Ammonia (30% in water)  (Toxic Liquid)
The following is the alternate release scenario description for aqueous ammonia:
If the transfer line from the aqueous ammonia storage tank failed (e.g. leaking gasket flange) outside of the storage tank containment dike and the transfer pump stayed on for 10 minutes, 4,500 pounds of aqueous ammonia would be released. The EPAA?s tabulated dispersion predictions for alternate release scenarios was used to determine the toxic endpoint.  This release could effect plant employees, if any were in the path of the wind in this remote section of the plant.  A small area of the plant to the north could be affected, depending on the weather conditions and the wind direction.  There are no residences or environmental receptors within the toxic endpoint circle.  Rupture of the transfer line is unlikely because of its design strength and the protection that the elevated pipe support route and structure strength provide.  In addition, plant personnel would be quickly alerted by the recognizable odor and stop the release before ten minutes had elapsed.

Alternate Release Scenario A? 1,3-Butadiene (Flammable refrigerated gas)
The following is the alternate scenario description for 1,3-butadiene:
If the three-inch transfer line from the storage tank to the production building failed outside of the storage area containment dike, the entire contents of the transfer line from storage to the production unit, 5,200 pounds, would be released.  The storage tank excess flow valve would automatically close, limiting further loss.  Effects from a vapor cloud explosion, flash fire, and a fireball were estimated using EPAA?s calculation method

ology. A fireball was estimated as the consequence that could have the farthest effect.  This release would effect plant employees if they were in this remote location.  A small area of the plant to the north could be affected, and this release could affect the neighboring plantA?s employees if they were in this remote location. There are no residences or environmental receptors within this toxic endpoint circle.  However, rupture of the transfer line is unlikely because of its strength and the protection that the pipe support route and structure strength provide.

10.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

The plant focus on safety is strong throughout the Rohm and Haas Company, which was recently acquired by the Dow Chemical Company.  Rohm and Haas continuously looks for ways to reduce risks and to improve safety performance.  Our safety program is integrated into all parts of plant operation and involves the identification and implementation of ways to improve safety performance.  For example, the plant switched from ammonia gas to aqueous ammonia (30% ammonia in water) in the late 1980A?s in order to reduce risk.  Also, the plant has achieved OSHAA?s Voluntary Protection Program certification.  The plant continues to identify and implement other safety improvement opportunities.
